oai_dc:dc.dc:title: American Brake Shoe Factory Workers
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stokes (photographer?)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Work
African Americans -- Employment
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: African American workmen inside a large wooden truss structure, with clerestory windows and back windows providing light. Some are shown with two wheeled carts laden with stacks of parts, others are standing on either side of a long worktable with tools, or stacking and moving parts. A slender white man wearing a short collarless jacket and flat cap stands at center with his hands behind his back. Written on the photograph at lower center is "American Breake (sic) Shoe F'd'y" and "Stokes" at lower right.

The American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company was established in 1902 in New Jersey. The company had manufacturing plants in Chattanooga; Buffalo, NY; Burnside, IL; Chicago, IL; Erie, PA; Baltimore, MD and many other cities.
